prompts.createTask:
Pause your roleplay and generate a list of tasks to complete an objective. Your next response must be formatted as a numbered list of plain text entries. Do not include anything but the numbered list. The list must be prioritized in the order that tasks must be completed.

The objective that you must make a numbered task list for is: [{{objective}}].
The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly. Be sure to include the objective as the final task.

Given an example objective of 'Make me a four course dinner', here is an example output:
1. Determine what the courses will be
2. Find recipes for each course
3. Go shopping for supplies with {{user}}
4. Cook the food
5. Get {{user}} to set the table
6. Serve the food
7. Enjoy eating the meal with {{user}}
prompts.checkTaskCompleted:
Pause your roleplay. Determine if this task is completed: [{{task}}].
To do this, examine the most recent messages. Your response must only contain either true or false, nothing other words.
Example output:
true
prompts.currentTask: Your current task is [{{task}}]. Balance existing roleplay with completing this task.

name: Coding Sensei
Gira
Coding Sensei
mes:
*With a flicker of digital light, Coding Sensei materializes into the chat.*

Ah, Gira! This is a React Native project with Expo. You're using some really useful libraries here like `react-native-paper` for Material Design components and `expo-router` for navigation.

This piece of code defines your RootLayout component that wraps around all other screens in your app. It uses custom fonts (`SpaceMono`, FontAwesome), and it ensures they are loaded before rendering anything else to avoid any flashes during load times.

The theme object you've created includes colors used throughout your app - nice work on customization there!

Lastly, it's good to see you're catching errors at this high level in case something goes wrong down the tree. An error boundary will catch JavaScript errors anywhere in their child component tree, log those errors, and display a fallback UI instead of crashing.

Remember: Error boundaries only catch errors in the components below them in the tree. They do not recognize exceptions thrown within its own component body or lifecycle methods.

So far so good! Do you need help with anything specific about this?

name: Gira
mes:
Yes. I'm using react native paper in my app. It uses PaperProvider. I would assume this wraps my entire app in paper provider, but:
1. It does not appear to wrap any of my pages in paper provider
2. I'm not sure how it wraps any of my pages

I was wondering, could you made sense of this for me? I'm not very big on the uptake

name: Coding Sensei
Gira
mes: I see! I notice you have removed rootlayout Nav entirely?
